message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s elevated glucose levels despite metformin and lifestyle modifications suggest the need for insulin therapy. Basal-bolus insulin involves the use of long-acting basal insulin and rapid-acting bolus insulin before meals to provide both basal and prandial glucose control. Adding basal insulin to metformin may not provide adequate glucose control for this patient. Sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 inhibitors can cause diabetic ketoacidosis in patients with elevated glucose levels, making it a poor choice for this patient. Thiazolidinediones have a delayed onset of action and may not provide rapid glucose control.
